questions.explanation: You should always exercise caution when driving near a stopped bus. There could be passengers in the vicinity and the bus may either prevent them from seeing you or you from seeing them.

questions.question: If an applicant does not receive an air brakes endorsement:
questions.answerA: They cannot operate a vehicle with air brakes.
questions.answerB: They can only operate a vehicle with air brakes in intrastate commerce.
questions.answerC: They can only operate a vehicle with air brakes in interstate commerce.
questions.explanation: If you wish to be licensed to drive a CMV with air brakes, you must pass the air brakes knowledge test and use a vehicle with air brakes for your skills test.

questions.question: If there is a cargo fire in a box trailer:
questions.answerA: The trailer doors should be opened.
questions.answerB: The trailer doors should not be opened.
questions.answerC: A large, heavy blanket should be put over the trailer.
questions.explanation: The doors of a trailer should be not be opened in the event of a cargo fire, especially if the cargo includes hazardous materials. Opening trailer doors would increase the fire's oxygen supply, potentially causing the fire to increase in size.

questions.question: As part of a pre-trip inspection, you should look for all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Tires with too much air pressure.
questions.answerB: Tires with too much wear.
questions.answerC: Tires made by different manufacturers.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires, verify that there is tread depth of at least 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires and tread depth of at least 2/32 of an inch in grooves on the other tires. Be sure that your tires are not too worn, are not cracked, have proper air pressure, and are all equally sized.

questions.question: To prevent a vehicle from rolling backward when beginning to move forward from a stopped position, you should:
questions.answerB: Partly engage the clutch.
questions.answerC: Apply the emergency brake.
questions.explanation: To prevent a vehicle with manual transmission from rolling backward when you begin to move forward from a stopped position, you can partly engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake pedal.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.answerB: The nuts are loose.
questions.answerC: The tires should be replaced.
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts can indicate that the nuts are loose. If you find rust near the wheel nuts, check their tightness before beginning to drive.

questions.question: How do ice cream trucks become hazardous to other drivers?
questions.answerA: Ice cream trucks must be kept cold.
questions.answerB: Children often run toward an ice cream truck without looking for other traffic.
questions.answerC: Ice cream trucks leave trails of water and ice on the roadway.
questions.explanation: Ice cream trucks can create hazardous conditions for other drivers because they attract children. Children often do not notice or pay attention to other vehicles on the roadway when running to or from ice cream trucks.

questions.question: A Class 1 hazardous material is:
questions.answerB: Radioactive.
questions.answerC: Corrosive.
questions.explanation: The first hazardous materials class includes explosives such as ammunition, dynamite, and fireworks.

questions.question: In low temperatures, bridges usually freeze:
questions.answerA: After other parts of the roadway.
questions.answerB: Before other parts of the roadway.
questions.answerC: At the same time as other parts of the roadway.
questions.explanation: In low temperatures, bridges usually freeze before other road surfaces. When driving in cold weather, especially when weather conditions have been wet, use special caution on bridges and overpasses.

questions.question: If a vehicle is carrying hazardous cargo, placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: Only on the front of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: On the front, rear, and sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Only on the driver’s side of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Placards must be placed on the front, the rear, and both sides of a vehicle carrying hazardous cargo. They must be readable from any direction.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are on, you should:
questions.answerB: Press the accelerator.
questions.answerC: Move the steering wheel.
questions.explanation: Do not use the brake pedal when the spring brakes are on. This could damage the brakes by subjecting them to the combined forces of springs and air pressure.

questions.question: If a driver has stopped on the road and is placing triangles to warn other motorists:
questions.answerA: The triangles should be held between the driver and oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: The triangles should be carried behind the driver's back to prevent them from being seen by other drivers until they are placed.
questions.answerC: The triangles should be held as low as possible.
questions.explanation: For your own safety, when placing reflective warning triangles, you should carry them between your body and the oncoming traffic.

questions.question: Tie-downs are used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent skidding.
questions.answerC: Keep doors closed while driving.
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers, cargo must be secured by tie-downs to keep it from shifting or falling off while the vehicle is in motion. Tie-downs may also be used to prevent cargo shifting in closed vans. Shifting cargo could affect the handling of a vehicle.

questions.question: When approaching a construction worker who is near the road, you should:
questions.answerB: Decrease your speed.
questions.answerC: Move to the shoulder.
questions.explanation: Always drive with caution through work zones. You should make a particular point of reducing your speed when workers are on or near the roadway.

questions.question: How much water must be present for a vehicle to hydroplane?
questions.answerB: A good amount, such as a large puddle
questions.answerC: A small amount
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is an effect in which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the surface of the road and instead glide along a layer of water. There does not have to be much water on the road for this to occur.

questions.question: If you are convicted of a traffic violation:
questions.answerA: The State will inform your employer.
questions.answerB: You must tell your employer.
questions.answerC: You must tell the shipper.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any kind of traffic violation, in any type of vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days. You must also inform your motor vehicle licensing agency of the violation within 30 days if the conviction happened in another jurisdiction. This rule does not apply to parking infractions.

questions.question: When driving, you should stop every ____ to take a break to avoid becoming too tired.
questions.answerB: Two hours
questions.answerC: Six hours
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of becoming fatigued on a long trip, you should stop to take a break at least once for every two hours or 100 miles driven.

questions.question: When approaching a school bus stop, the bus driver should:
questions.answerB: Approach the stop with caution.
questions.answerC: Stop on the sidewalk.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should always approach bus stops slowly and cautiously.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection and looking into the fifth wheel gap, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure the locking jaws are open.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.
questions.answerC: Make sure the locking jaws are loose.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a trailer coupling, you should make sure the fifth wheel locking jaws are closed around the shank of the kingpin, not the head of the kingpin.

questions.question: When boarding a school bus, students should:
questions.answerB: Be in pairs.
questions.answerC: Not use the handrail.
questions.explanation: Students should board a school bus slowly and in a single-file line. For safety, boarding students should use the handrail.

questions.question: When dropping off students at a school, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Secure the bus by turning off the engine.
questions.answerB: Leave the key in the ignition, if leaving the driver’s compartment.
questions.answerC: Read a book while students unload.
questions.explanation: When unloading students at a school, a bus driver must secure the bus by turning off the engine. If they must leave the driver's compartment, they should remove the key from the ignition. The driver must supervise the unloading process.

questions.question: Adjust a bus's mirrors:
questions.answerB: While operating the bus.
questions.answerC: At the first stoplight after starting your shift.
questions.explanation: The adjustment of mirrors should be checked prior to the start of any trip.

questions.question: If your bus is equipped with a roof-mounted strobe light, it should be used:
questions.answerB: All the time.
questions.answerC: Only at night.
questions.explanation: If equipped, a school bus's roof-mounted strobe light should be used when conditions create an environment of limited visibility.

questions.question: When students are being picked up by a school bus:
questions.answerA: The students should wait at a designated bus stop.
questions.answerB: The driver should pick up students whether or not they are at the designated bus stop.
questions.answerC: The parents should choose where the bus stop will be located.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should load and unload students only at designated stops that have been approved by appropriate school district officials.

questions.question: Loading and unloading a bus:
questions.answerB: Should be supervised by someone other than the driver.
questions.answerC: Should be done when refueling.
questions.explanation: Passengers may stumble when getting on or off of a school bus. The driver should caution passengers to watch their step when exiting.

questions.question: When students board a bus, they should:
questions.answerA: Sit in the back row first.
questions.answerB: Sit in the back row only after all other seats are filled.
questions.answerC: Be seated as far from the driver as possible.
questions.explanation: Students should not occupy the back row of a school bus unless the bus is full. The closer to the front of a bus that students are seated, the safer they will be in the event of a rear-end collision. Students with special needs should sit near the driver.

questions.question: When loading or unloading passengers, a school bus should be placed in ____ if there is no park shift point available.
questions.answerB: First gear
questions.answerC: Neutral
questions.explanation: When stopping to load or unload students, a school bus should ideally be placed in park. If there is no park shift point, the bus should be placed in neutral and the parking brake should be set.

questions.question: If a bus must be evacuated, it is safest for students to:
questions.answerA: Stand no more than 50 feet away from the bus.
questions.answerB: Stand downwind of the bus in the event of a fire.
questions.answerC: Be led far away from any railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: After evacuating a school bus, students should be led to a safe place at least 100 feet away from the road in the direction of oncoming traffic. This will keep them safe from flying debris if another vehicle hits the bus. Students should be upwind of any fires and as far away from railroad tracks as possible.

questions.question: When students are boarding a school bus, the driver should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Check all mirrors for students rushing toward the bus.
questions.answerB: Count the number of students at the bus stop and ensure all have boarded.
questions.answerC: Allow student to board in pairs.
questions.explanation: When approaching a bus stop, a school bus driver should count the number of students waiting and ensure that they all board the bus. The driver should check their mirrors for any students who may be running to the stop. Students should board slowly in a single-file line.

questions.question: When a school bus is approaching a bus stop, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Approach with caution.
questions.answerC: Drive quickly and stop abruptly.
questions.explanation: School bus drivers should approach stops slowly and cautiously.

questions.question: An encroachment is when:
questions.answerA: A driver does not appear for their scheduled basic skills test.
questions.answerB: A vehicle touches an exercise boundary line during the basic skills test.
questions.answerC: A driver fails one section of the basic skills test.
questions.explanation: An encroachment during the basic vehicle control skills test is when an exercise boundary line is touched or crossed by any portion of the applicant's vehicle. Every encroachment will be counted as an error.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to adequately check all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: The water compressor belt.
questions.answerC: The alternator belt.
questions.explanation: During the pre-trip vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to check the power steering, water pump, alternator, and air compressor belts, if the vehicle is equipped.

questions.question: Before a trip, you should make sure that:
questions.answerB: The gas pedal is loose.
questions.answerC: The grooved pedal surface has not been smoothed out.
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's pedals during a pre-trip inspection, you should ensure that there is nothing under or around the pedals that will obstruct their use. Make sure the pedals are in proper working condition and that the surfaces of the pedals are grooved, if applicable.

questions.question: If you come to railroad tracks while driving a school bus, you should generally:
questions.answerA: Check the tracks, but continue driving without stopping.
questions.answerB: Stop 15 to 50 feet before the nearest rail.
questions.answerC: Stop 75 feet before the nearest rail.
questions.explanation: In general, school bus drivers should stop before any railroad crossings to check the tracks for approaching trains. Drivers should stop no closer than 15 feet and no farther than 50 feet from the nearest rail in order to have the best view of the tracks. They should look and listen for approaching trains before proceeding through the crossing.

questions.question: The inside rearview mirror is used to:
questions.answerB: See potential hazards on the road.
questions.answerC: See vehicles trying to switch lanes.
questions.explanation: The overhead inside rearview mirror in a school bus is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: As a general rule, where should students be kept during an emergency?
questions.answerB: On the side of the road near the bus
questions.answerC: In a field away from the bus
questions.explanation: In most emergency or crisis situations, students on a school bus will be safer and more easily controlled if they are kept on the bus than if they are evacuated. However, if staying on a bus will expose the students to risk or injury, the bus driver should escort them to a safe location.

questions.question: When making a stop to pick up students, a driver should ensure all surrounding traffic has stopped before:
questions.answerA: Opening the door and signaling for the students to approach.
questions.answerB: Turning on the alternating red lights.
questions.answerC: Pulling over to the side of the road.
questions.explanation: When stopping to pick up students, a school bus driver should ensure that all surrounding traffic has stopped before opening the door and signaling for the students to approach the bus.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle controls skills test exercise, your vehicle's final position should be:
questions.answerA: In the general area that was described by the examiner.
questions.answerB: In the exact final position described by the examiner.
questions.answerC: Within three feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.explanation: You should finish each exercise with your vehicle in the exact position described by the examiner. You can be penalized for failing to complete an exercise exactly in the manner described by the examiner, potentially resulting in failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: When students board a school bus, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Check all mirrors.
questions.answerC: Only look at the students.
questions.explanation: While students are boarding a school bus, the driver should supervise the loading while watching all mirrors for any students running to catch the bus.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Show where the dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Show that the engine oil is within safe operating range.
questions.answerC: Show that the oil is below the refill mark.
questions.explanation: During the pre-trip vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to indicate where the dipstick is located. You will need to show that the oil level is within a safe operating range and above the refill mark.

questions.question: Properly adjusted crossover mirrors allow you to see all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: The right and left front tires touching the ground.
questions.answerB: The area in front of the bus.
questions.answerC: The tops of the right and left rear tires.
questions.explanation: Properly adjusted crossover mirrors on a school bus should allow the driver to see the entire area in front of the bus, from the front bumper at ground level to a point where direct vision is possible. The mirrors should also display the right and left front tires touching the ground, as well as the area from the front of the bus to the service door.

questions.question: When completing a conventional parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Back up past the parking space, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward directly into the parking space.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a conventional parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the right of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: When students are being picked up by a school bus:
questions.answerA: The students should wait at a designated bus stop.
questions.answerB: The driver should stop to pick up students who are walking to a designated bus stop.
questions.answerC: The parents may choose where the bus stops are located.
questions.explanation: School bus drivers may only pick up students at official stops designated by authorized school officials.

questions.question: If you are stopped at a railroad crossing while operating a school bus, you should:
questions.answerA: Prepare to proceed as soon as a train passes.
questions.answerB: Ignore signs and signals.
questions.answerC: Open the door to listen for approaching trains.
questions.explanation: When stopped at a railroad crossing while operating a school bus, do not rely only on signals to tell you if a train is approaching. You should silence all passengers, open the front door, and look and listen for trains. After a train has passed, you should check for another train approaching from either direction before you proceed across the tracks.

questions.question: When exiting a vehicle, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Hop directly from their seat to the ground.
questions.answerB: Maintain at least one point of contact with their vehicle.
questions.answerC: Be turned to face their vehicle.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.

questions.question: When driving a school bus, mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.answerB: Before beginning to drive.
questions.answerC: By the students.
questions.explanation: You should always check the adjustment of all your mirrors before operating a school bus.

questions.question: Loading and unloading a bus:
questions.answerB: Does not need to be supervised.
questions.answerC: Should be done while refueling.
questions.explanation: More students are killed each year during loading or unloading of school buses than while riding on school buses. Therefore, it is critical that school bus drivers follow appropriate safety procedures during loading and unloading.

questions.question: When asked to make a turn while taking your driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signal, but only if other cars are present.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerC: Check traffic in all directions.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: When stopping to pick up students, be sure to park at least 10 feet away from the students because:
questions.answerA: You will have a good view of their movements.
questions.answerB: It will be difficult to get any closer to the students.
questions.answerC: Students should walk for exercise.
questions.explanation: When picking up passengers, a school bus driver should park with the vehicle's front bumper at least 10 feet away from the students. This is the safest parking option because it forces the students to walk to the bus, making it possible for the driver to watch their movements.

questions.question: When loading or unloading passengers, a school bus should be placed in ____ if there is no park shift point available.
questions.answerB: First gear
questions.answerC: Neutral
questions.explanation: When stopping to load or unload students, a school bus should ideally be placed in park. If there is no park shift point, the bus should be placed in neutral and the parking brake should be set.

questions.question: With the exception of the straight line backing exercise, a driver may exit their vehicle and check its position during testing exercises up to:
questions.answerB: Two times.
questions.answerC: Three times.
questions.explanation: A driver is allowed to exit their vehicle to check its position during any basic vehicle control skills test exercise. This action is called a "look." During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: The overhead rearview mirror is located:
questions.answerA: On the right side of a bus.
questions.answerB: On the steering wheel of a bus.
questions.answerC: Above the windshield inside a bus.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is mounted directly above the windshield on the driver’s side of the bus. This mirror should be used to monitor students inside the bus.

questions.question: If a gate controlling a railroad crossing does not go back up after a train passes, you should:
questions.answerB: Wait for another vehicle to cross the tracks first to see if it is safe.
questions.answerC: Call your dispatcher.
questions.explanation: If you are stopped at a railroad crossing and a gate fails to return to its open position after a train passes, call your dispatcher. Do not attempt to drive around the lowered gate.

questions.question: ABS helps you:
questions.answerB: Keep your wheels from locking up.
questions.answerC: Count the number of students boarding the bus.
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up when the driver brakes hard on a slippery surface.

questions.question: The inside rearview mirror is used to:
questions.answerB: See potential hazards on the road.
questions.answerC: See vehicles trying to switch lanes.
questions.explanation: The overhead inside rearview mirror in a school bus is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: If you must drive in reverse at a student pick-up point, you should:
questions.answerA: Back up before the students board the bus.
questions.answerB: Back up after the students board the bus.
questions.answerC: Back up while students direct you.
questions.explanation: Backing in a school bus is strongly discouraged and should be done only if there is no other safe way to move the vehicle. If you must drive in reverse at a student pick-up point, you should wait until all students have first loaded the bus.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Show where the power steering fluid dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Check for adequate power steering fluid.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the power steering fluid level is above the full mark.
questions.explanation: During the pre-trip vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to indicate where the power steering fluid dipstick or reservoir sight glass is located. You will need to show that the power steering fluid is within a safe operating range.

questions.question: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be:
questions.answerA: Inside a gas station looking through a window.
questions.answerB: In the vehicle, awake or asleep.
questions.answerC: Within 100 feet of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be awake inside the vehicle or otherwise within 100 feet of the vehicle; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: A person should not smoke within ____ of a vehicle placarded for Class 3 or Division 2.1 materials.
questions.answerB: 25 feet
questions.answerC: 100 feet
questions.explanation: You should not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded cargo tank used to transport materials that are categorized as Class 3 (flammable liquids) or Division 2.1 (gases). Do not smoke or carry a lit cigar, pipe, or cigarette near a vehicle containing flammable or explosive materials.

questions.question: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must carry a fire extinguisher with a minimum rating of:
questions.explanation: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must be equipped with a fire extinguisher with an Underwriters Laboratories (UL) rating of 10 B:C or more.

questions.question: To transport hazardous materials, a driver needs:
questions.answerB: A CDL with hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: A CDL with a tank endorsement.
questions.explanation: To drive a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials, you must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement.

questions.question: Shipping papers must include:
questions.answerB: The price of the materials.
questions.answerC: The use of the materials.
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to include an emergency response telephone number on shipping papers.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle can only be moved:
questions.answerA: To make room for other vehicles.
questions.answerB: In an emergency.
questions.answerC: If the vehicle will be traveling fewer than 10 miles.
questions.explanation: A vehicle that has not been properly placarded may not be driven, except when necessary to protect life or property in an emergency.

questions.question: A placard indicating hazardous materials is which shape?
questions.answerB: Triangle
questions.answerC: Circle
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: When you are behind the steering wheel, shipping papers should be:
questions.answerB: In the sleeping compartment.
questions.answerC: Hidden under the seat.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: When refueling a vehicle carrying hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The engine should be left on.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The gas nozzle may be left unattended.
questions.explanation: If you need to refuel a vehicle carrying hazardous materials, you must first turn off the engine. While refueling, someone must be at the nozzle and controlling the fuel flow at all times.

questions.question: An indicator that cargo contains hazardous materials is:
questions.answerA: The cargo is stored in cylinder tanks.
questions.answerB: The cargo is picked up from a supermarket.
questions.answerC: The cargo is packaged in cardboard boxes.
questions.explanation: Packaging can be an indicator of whether or not materials are hazardous. Cylinders and drums are often used to hold and transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: When loading containers of hazardous materials, you should not use:
questions.answerB: Hooks.
questions.answerC: Straps.
questions.explanation: Always protect containers of hazardous materials. When loading hazardous materials, never use equipment that could damage containers or packaging, such as hooks.

questions.question: To know which placard to use, you need to know:
questions.answerA: The hazard class of the materials.
questions.answerB: The type of container that is holding the materials.
questions.answerC: The destination of the materials.
questions.explanation: To determine which placards need to be used, you must know the hazard class of the materials being shipped, the amount of hazardous materials being shipped, and the total weight of all hazardous materials in your vehicle.

questions.question: If transporting explosives:
questions.answerA: You must have a written route plan.
questions.answerB: You should take the shortest possible route.
questions.answerC: You can always use tunnels.
questions.explanation: If transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you must follow a written route plan. Whenever placarded, avoid heavily populated areas, crowds, tunnels, narrow streets, and alleys. Be sure to research any restrictions that may apply to the routes you plan to take.

questions.question: Placards showing the type of hazardous materials in a vehicle are usually which shape?
questions.answerB: A triangle
questions.answerC: A diamond
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: To complete a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest, you must:
questions.answerB: Only sign the manifest if you cross into another state.
questions.answerC: Have a witness sign the manifest.
questions.explanation: If you are transporting hazardous waste, you must carry with you a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest. The manifest must be signed by hand.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be in the vehicle?
questions.answerB: Goggles
questions.answerC: An axe
questions.explanation: If transporting chlorine in cargo tanks, a driver must have an approved gas mask in their vehicle.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle with empty cargo tanks that are used to transport hazardous materials, a driver:
questions.answerA: Should not cross a railroad crossing.
questions.answerB: Needs to slow when approaching a railroad crossing, but is not required to stop.
questions.answerC: Must stop at a railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has cargo tanks that are used to carry hazardous materials, you must stop before crossing railroad tracks. This is true whether the tanks are full or empty.

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking but the driver does not have access to a phone, they should:
questions.answerA: Drive to a phone to alert emergency personnel.
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean-up facility.
questions.answerC: Send someone else for help.
questions.explanation: If a cargo of hazardous materials begins to leak, do not move your vehicle any more than safety requires. If you continue to drive, an even larger area will become contaminated. Instead, you should park your vehicle, secure it, stay with the vehicle, and contact the proper emergency personnel. If you do not have access to a phone, you should send someone else to get help.

questions.question: A placard should be placed:
questions.answerA: At least three inches away from any other markings.
questions.answerB: Under a ladder, if space is an issue.
questions.answerC: On a background that is a similar color to the placard.
questions.explanation: A placard must be placed at least three inches away from any other markings. The placard should be kept clear of attachments or devices, such as doors and ladders. Placards should always be placed against a background of a contrasting color.

questions.question: If loading corrosive materials, you should not:
questions.answerB: Load the containers by hand.
questions.answerC: Use the vehicle’s parking brake.
questions.explanation: If loading by hand, load breakable containers of corrosive liquid one by one. Keep them facing upright. Do not drop or roll the containers.

questions.question: How often are hazardous materials employees required to be trained and tested?
questions.answerB: Once every three years
questions.answerC: Once every five years
questions.explanation: All drivers must be trained in the security risks of hazardous materials transportation. This training must include how to recognize and respond to possible security threats. Hazardous materials employees must be trained and tested at least once every three years.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The hazardous materials must be listed first.
questions.answerB: The hazardous materials must be written larger.
questions.answerC: The hazardous materials must be listed in red ink.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper lists both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be entered first.

questions.question: What is the symbol for a marine pollutant?
questions.answerA: The image of a bird in a red octagon
questions.answerB: The image of a fish in a white triangle with an X through through the fish
questions.answerC: A light blue square with a dark blue X through the square
questions.explanation: The marine pollutant symbol is the image of a fish in a white triangle with an X through through the fish.

questions.question: If the letter “G” appears in Column 1 of a hazardous materials shipping paper, the shipping paper must also include:
questions.answerA: The technical name of the hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: The type of packaging containing the hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: The shipper’s phone number.
questions.explanation: A "G" in Column 1 of a hazardous materials shipping paper indicates that the description in Column 2 is the generic name for a material. A generic shipping name must be accompanied by a technical name.

questions.question: Before loading or unloading flammable liquids, the engine should be:
questions.answerB: Revved up.
questions.answerC: Left on.
questions.explanation: Unless you must run the engine to operate a pump, you should always turn off the engine before loading or unloading flammable liquids.

questions.question: Unless the package is clearly unsafe, a driver needs ____ to accept a package.
questions.answerB: A notarized statement
questions.answerC: A verbal agreement
questions.explanation: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify that the package has been prepared according to Hazardous Materials Regulations (HMR). Unless a package is clearly unsafe or noncomplying with HMR, you may accept the shipper’s certification concerning the proper packaging of a material.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerA: The shipping paper matches the markings and labels on packages.
questions.answerB: The shipping paper is written in code.
questions.answerC: All packages are labeled as poison.
questions.explanation: It is always a good idea to compare package markings and labels to accompanying shipping papers. Always make sure the shipper has displayed the correct basic description on the shipping paper and has provided the proper labels on the packages.

questions.question: A manifest for transporting hazardous waste:
questions.answerB: Must be sent electronically.
questions.answerC: Must be attached to the outside of the trailer.
questions.explanation: If you are transporting hazardous waste, you must carry with you a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest. The manifest must be signed by hand.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are usually shaped like:
questions.answerB: Triangles.
questions.answerC: Diamonds.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are usually diamond-shaped.

questions.question: Which type of material may be required to have a transport index?
questions.answerB: Combustible
questions.answerC: Radioactive
questions.explanation: Some radioactive materials are required to be accompanied by a transport index. A transport index is a number that indicates how much control the material will require during transport. The total transport index of all cargo in a single vehicle may not exceed 50.

questions.question: Hazardous materials shipping papers may not be kept:
questions.answerA: In a pouch on the driver’s door.
questions.answerB: In a pouch on the passenger’s side door.
questions.answerC: Within reach of the driver while the seat belt is fastened.
questions.explanation: Shipping papers must be quickly accessible in the event of an emergency. While driving, operators must keep the papers in a pouch on the driver’s door or in clear view and within immediate reach while their seat belt is fastened. Shipping papers may be kept on the driver’s seat when the driver is out of the vehicle.

questions.question: If "Inhalation Hazard" appears on a shipping paper, the shipper should provide which placard?
questions.answerB: Poison Gas or Poison Inhalation Hazard
questions.answerC: Reportable Quantity
questions.explanation: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on the shipping paper or package, you must display the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" or "Poison Gas" placards, as appropriate.

questions.question: How often are hazardous materials employees required to be trained and tested?
questions.answerB: Once every three years
questions.answerC: Once every five years
questions.explanation: All drivers must be trained in the security risks of hazardous materials transportation. This training must include how to recognize and respond to possible security threats. Hazardous materials employees must be trained and tested at least once every three years.

questions.question: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must carry a fire extinguisher with a minimum rating of:
questions.explanation: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must be equipped with a fire extinguisher with an Underwriters Laboratories (UL) rating of 10 B:C or more.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are usually shaped like:
questions.answerB: Triangles.
questions.answerC: Diamonds.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are usually diamond-shaped.

questions.question: What is the symbol for a marine pollutant?
questions.answerA: The image of a bird in a red octagon
questions.answerB: The image of a fish in a white triangle with an X through through the fish
questions.answerC: A light blue square with a dark blue X through the square
questions.explanation: The marine pollutant symbol is the image of a fish in a white triangle with an X through through the fish.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle can only be moved:
questions.answerA: To make room for other vehicles.
questions.answerB: In an emergency.
questions.answerC: If the vehicle will be traveling fewer than 10 miles.
questions.explanation: A vehicle that has not been properly placarded may not be driven, except when necessary to protect life or property in an emergency.

questions.question: Before loading or unloading flammable liquids, the engine should be:
questions.answerB: Revved up.
questions.answerC: Left on.
questions.explanation: Unless you must run the engine to operate a pump, you should always turn off the engine before loading or unloading flammable liquids.

questions.question: If transporting hazardous materials, a shipper should warn others by:
questions.answerA: Posting HazMat placards on their truck.
questions.answerB: Putting flashing lights on their truck.
questions.answerC: Sounding a siren.
questions.explanation: Shippers of certain kinds of hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs, known as placards, on any transporting vehicles. Shippers are required to provide applicable placards, labels, shipping papers, and emergency response information.

questions.question: Shippers package in order to ____ hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Release
questions.answerC: Insulate
questions.explanation: Shippers package hazardous materials in a way that is meant to completely contain the materials. Vehicles should be placarded to communicate the risk of the cargo.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1 explosives, you must park at least ____ from any building.
questions.answerB: 50 feet
questions.answerC: 300 feet
questions.explanation: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, do not park within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building; a place where people gather; or an open fire.

questions.question: Hazardous materials may be transported:
questions.answerA: By any driver with a CDL.
questions.answerB: By a driver with a CDL and hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: In rural areas by any driver.
questions.explanation: You must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to operate a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.answerC: Made of cardboard.
questions.explanation: Containers of hazardous materials should be braced so they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation.

questions.question: How do you label a package if the hazardous materials label will not fit onto the package?
questions.answerA: Place the label on a tag securely attached to the item.
questions.answerB: Attach a QR Code to be scanned.
questions.answerC: Reduce the size of the HazMat label to fit it completely on the item.
questions.explanation: Shippers should place applicable diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on hazardous materials packages. If a label will not fit entirely onto a package, shippers may instead place the label on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: Many products classed as poison are also:
questions.answerB: Flammable.
questions.answerC: Gases.
questions.explanation: Many hazardous materials classified as poisonous are also flammable.

questions.question: You may leave a vehicle that is carrying explosives unattended:
questions.answerB: In a safe haven.
questions.answerC: On the shoulder of a highway.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: To transport hazardous materials, a driver needs:
questions.answerB: A CDL with hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: A CDL with a tank endorsement.
questions.explanation: To drive a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials, you must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement.

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.answerB: The loader
questions.answerC: The driver
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials. They must supply the warning placards.

questions.question: The identification numbers assigned to chemicals can be found:
questions.answerA: In the DOT Emergency Response Guide.
questions.answerB: In the truck's manual.
questions.answerC: In the Periodic Table of Elements.
questions.explanation: Information about hazardous chemicals is found in the Emergency Response Guide (ERG) provided by U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT). The ERG is indexed by the proper shipping names and identification numbers of substances.

questions.question: If the letter “G” appears in Column 1 of a hazardous materials shipping paper, the shipping paper must also include:
questions.answerA: The technical name of the hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: The type of packaging containing the hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: The shipper’s phone number.
questions.explanation: A "G" in Column 1 of a hazardous materials shipping paper indicates that the description in Column 2 is the generic name for a material. A generic shipping name must be accompanied by a technical name.

questions.question: Unless the package is clearly unsafe, a driver needs ____ to accept a package.
questions.answerB: A notarized statement
questions.answerC: A verbal agreement
questions.explanation: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify that the package has been prepared according to Hazardous Materials Regulations (HMR). Unless a package is clearly unsafe or noncomplying with HMR, you may accept the shipper’s certification concerning the proper packaging of a material.

questions.question: During a cargo fire, opening the trailer doors may actually cause the fire to expand because doing so:
questions.answerB: Changes the temperature of the trailer.
questions.answerC: Provides more moisture to the trailer.
questions.explanation: When experiencing a cargo fire, it may be a bad idea to open the doors to the trailer. Doing so allows oxygen to enter the area, potentially causing the fire to flare up and expand.

questions.question: If you are transporting hazardous materials and the cargo catches on fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to put out the fire with a fire extinguisher.
questions.answerB: Contact emergency personnel and let them battle the fire.
questions.answerC: Continue driving to the fire department.
questions.explanation: Fighting a hazardous materials fire requires specialized training and equipment. Unless you possess these yourself, it is best to let emergency personnel deal with the fire.

questions.question: Hazardous materials shipping papers may be:
questions.answerA: Kept in a pouch attached to the driver's side door.
questions.answerB: Taped to the passenger's side window.
questions.answerC: Hidden under a seat.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: As a driver, which of the following is not your job at the scene of an accident?
questions.answerA: Keeping people away from the scene.
questions.answerB: Taking heroic measures to put the fire out.
questions.answerC: Communicating the danger of the hazardous materials to response personnel.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in an accident while carrying hazardous materials, it is your responsibility as the driver to keep people away from the scene; limit the spread of material if you can safely do so; inform emergency response personnel of the dangers posed by the materials; and provide emergency personnel with the shipping papers and emergency response information. Unless you have protective equipment and the necessary training, do not try to fight hazardous materials fires yourself.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 materials should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.answerB: An air conditioner.
questions.answerC: Other items.
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gases), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids), the use of heaters in the same space is generally prohibited.

questions.question: Placards showing the type of hazardous materials in a vehicle are usually which shape?
questions.answerB: A triangle
questions.answerC: A diamond
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerA: The shipping paper matches the markings and labels on packages.
questions.answerB: The shipping paper is written in code.
questions.answerC: All packages are labeled as poison.
questions.explanation: It is always a good idea to compare package markings and labels to accompanying shipping papers. Always make sure the shipper has displayed the correct basic description on the shipping paper and has provided the proper labels on the packages.

questions.question: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, your vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.answerC: Driven in rain or snow.
questions.explanation: Except when parking briefly to perform necessary functions for vehicle operation (such as refueling), never park a vehicle carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building. Never park such a vehicle within five feet of the traveled portion of the road.

questions.question: If a package of explosives has an oily stain or shows dampness, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Decline transporting the load.
questions.answerC: Use towels to absorb the liquid.
questions.explanation: You should never transport damaged packages of explosives. Do not accept a package that seems damp or has an oily stain.

questions.question: If you are backing and the trailer begins to drift off-course, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Return the steering wheel to the 12 o’clock position.
questions.answerB: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction of the drift.
questions.answerC: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the drift.
questions.explanation: If your trailer begins to drift while you are backing, you should correct the drift immediately by turning the top of the steering wheel in the direction of the drift.

questions.question: What is the Johnson bar?
questions.answerA: A hand valve that works the trailer brakes
questions.answerB: A valve that indicates the fuel level
questions.answerC: A valve that limits the amount of cargo
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve, also called the trolley valve or Johnson bar, is used to work the trailer brakes. It should be used only to test the brakes. Using it while a vehicle is in motion could cause a skid.

questions.question: Landing gear should be ____ during uncoupling.
questions.answerB: Fully raised
questions.answerC: Firmly on the ground
questions.explanation: Landing gear, or trailer supports, should always be completely raised before a vehicle is driven. When uncoupling, landing gear should be lowered to make firm contact with the ground. If a trailer is loaded when it is being uncoupled, you should lower the landing gear and turn the crank a few additional times to remove some weight from the trailer.

questions.question: When coupling, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure to couple the proper glad hands.
questions.answerB: Only couple one set of glad hands.
questions.answerC: It is best to leave one glad hand loose.
questions.explanation: When coupling air brake hoses, you should make sure the proper pairs of gland hands are connected. They are sometimes color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: In a double or triple combination, the ____ trailer should be directly behind the cab.
questions.answerB: Heaviest
questions.answerC: Smallest
questions.explanation: When positioning trailers in a combination, the most heavily-loaded trailer should be the closest to the tractor. The lightest trailer should be positioned in the rear.

questions.question: Roads are especially slippery when it first begins to rain because:
questions.answerB: The fresh rain mixes with oil on the roadway.
questions.answerC: The water has nowhere to go.
questions.explanation: Roads are particularly slippery when it first begins to rain. The water mixes with oil drippings on the road that have not yet washed away, creating a slippery and dangerous mixture.

questions.question: You should check and adjust your mirrors:
questions.answerB: While driving.
questions.answerC: After driving.
questions.explanation: Be sure to check your mirrors before beginning a drive. Your posture may change day to day and your mirrors may need to be adjusted.

questions.question: Having ABS on only one axle:
questions.answerB: Still allows you additional control when braking.
questions.answerC: Slows the vehicle, but cannot stop it.
questions.explanation: If you have an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) equipped on only the tractor, only the trailer, or only one axle, you will still have more control over the vehicle when braking than you would without ABS. You should brake normally.

questions.question: Mirror adjustment can only be checked properly if:
questions.answerB: There is no trailer.
questions.answerC: The vehicle is on a slight incline.
questions.explanation: On a vehicle with one or more trailers, mirror adjustment can only be checked accurately if the trailers are straight. Mirror adjustment should be checked before the start of every trip.

questions.question: When entering traffic, a large vehicle usually needs:
questions.answerA: Less space than is needed for a car.
questions.answerB: About the same amount of space as is needed for a car.
questions.answerC: More space than is needed for a car.
questions.explanation: A large vehicle requires more space when entering or crossing traffic than a smaller vehicle. This is not only because the vehicle itself is larger, but also because it needs a longer distance to accelerate.

questions.question: What is removed when an air tank is drained?
questions.answerB: Ammonia
questions.answerC: Liquid cleaners
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, air tanks have drains to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. Allowing water and oil to accumulate in the system could cause damage to the brakes.

questions.question: To stay alert while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Eat a heavy meal before beginning your trip.
questions.answerB: Keep the cab warm.
questions.answerC: Ride with a second person who can share driving responsibilities.
questions.explanation: Splitting driving responsibilities with a second driver lowers the chance that either of you will drive while fatigued. You can also reduce the risk of fatigue by avoiding heavy foods and keeping the interior of the cab cool.

questions.question: How much distance will an air brake-equipped vehicle need to come to a complete stop if it is traveling at 55 mph under ideal driving conditions?
questions.answerB: 100 feet
questions.answerC: 450 feet
questions.explanation: A vehicle's total stopping distance is made up of perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. With all of these factors included, an air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately 450 feet to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: An example of required emergency equipment is:
questions.answerB: A loud horn.
questions.answerC: A battery-operated flashlight.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle unattended:
questions.answerA: The parking brake should be used.
questions.answerB: The parking brake only needs to be used if the vehicle is parked on a slope.
questions.answerC: The parking brake should not be used, as it can damage the tires.
questions.explanation: In general, you should always use the parking brake when parking your vehicle. However, you should not apply the parking brake if your brakes are very hot or if your brakes are wet and temperatures are below freezing.

questions.question: If your vehicle is hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn the steering wheel as hard as possible.
questions.answerB: Not use the brakes.
questions.answerC: Put the vehicle in reverse.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, do not apply the brakes. Instead, slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch. This will help you to regain traction.

questions.question: The "crack-the-whip" effect is caused by:
questions.answerB: Driving below the speed limit.
questions.answerC: Heavy traffic.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with trailers are vulnerable to rollover due to the "crack-the-whip" effect, which is caused by rearward amplification. Rearward amplification varies from vehicle to vehicle, so it is important that drivers are aware of the rearward amplification of their specific vehicles.

questions.question: A driver can rely on front wheel braking to work:
questions.answerB: Under all conditions.
questions.answerC: Under all conditions, except for snow.
questions.explanation: Front wheel braking is effective under all road conditions. It is unlikely that you will experience a front wheel skid, even on ice.

questions.question: A person driving with an open window in cold weather may be:
questions.answerB: A person who is dressed inappropriately.
questions.answerC: A person who likes fresh air.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' actions and identify clues that a person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. One sign that a driver may be impaired is that they have their windows rolled down in cold weather.

questions.question: Vehicles driving behind a truck:
questions.answerA: May have difficulty seeing objects in front of the truck.
questions.answerB: Often have a great view of the roadway in front of them.
questions.answerC: Do not need to signal.
questions.explanation: Your truck may block the views of drivers behind you, making them unaware of any upcoming hazards that require you to stop. For this reason, it is a good idea to flash your brakes and warn other drivers before slowing or stopping.

questions.question: Doubles combinations:
questions.answerA: Are less likely to jackknife than singles.
questions.answerB: Are less likely to roll over than singles.
questions.answerC: Require a larger reaction time than singles.
questions.explanation: Because doubles and triples are more vulnerable than singles to jackknifing and rolling over, drivers should look far ahead of their vehicles so they can react to hazards well in advance and slow down or change lanes gradually.

questions.question: Using a helper when backing up a large vehicle is:
questions.answerB: Discouraged.
questions.answerC: Illegal.
questions.explanation: Backing a CMV is always dangerous due to limited visibility, so using a helper to monitor your blind spots is encouraged whenever possible.

questions.question: If using spring brakes when hauling a heavy load, a complete stop will:
questions.answerB: Take a long time.
questions.answerC: Take a short amount of time.
questions.explanation: Spring brakes do not work on all axles. If your vehicle's spring brakes activate due to low pressure in an air brake system, your vehicle will need a longer distance to stop than usual, especially if you are carrying a heavy load.

questions.question: If you doubt that you have enough space to safely drive under a bridge or sign, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive more slowly.
questions.answerC: Drive on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: If you are not certain that your vehicle will fit under overhead objects, you should slow down and take a different route, if possible.

questions.question: What can happen if the exhaust system is not working properly?
questions.answerA: Poisonous fumes may enter the cab.
questions.answerB: Fumes may exit the rear of the muffler system.
questions.answerC: Proper steering may be impossible.
questions.explanation: Leaks in an exhaust system are extremely dangerous because they may allow toxic fumes into the cab or sleeper berth, endangering drivers and passengers.

questions.question: During a trip, landing gear should be:
questions.answerB: Completely lowered.
questions.answerC: Skimming the pavement.
questions.explanation: Landing gear, or trailer supports, should always be completely raised before a vehicle is driven. Landing gear that is not entirely raised could catch on railroad tracks or other hazards on the roadway.

questions.question: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS):
questions.answerB: Are only used on tucks carrying hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Allow drivers to stay in control when braking.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps prevent wheels from locking up during a hard application of brakes.

questions.question: Before driving a power steering-equipped vehicle, you should make sure that:
questions.answerA: The fluid is at a proper level.
questions.answerB: The hoses are connected to the battery.
questions.answerC: Any leak is small.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle that is equipped with power steering, check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. In particular, you should look for leaks in the hoses.

questions.question: If a vehicle begins to hydroplane, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Release the accelerator and push in the clutch.
questions.answerC: Pull in the clutch and brake.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, you can regain control by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch.

questions.question: While operating on a downgrade, you should brake until you reach a speed that is:
questions.answerB: 10 mph below your safe speed.
questions.answerC: 15 mph below your safe speed.
questions.explanation: While driving downhill, you should hold down the brake pedal until your vehicle reaches a speed 5 mph below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal. Repeat this process.

questions.question: Fully-loaded rigs:
questions.answerA: Are less likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerB: Are more likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerC: Are just as likely to roll over as empty rigs.
questions.explanation: Fully-loaded rigs are more vulnerable to rolling over than empty rigs because the weight of the cargo gives the vehicles higher centers of gravity.

questions.question: You should maintain at least ____ of following distance per every 10 feet of your vehicle when you are traveling more slowly than 40 mph.
questions.answerB: Two seconds
questions.answerC: Three seconds
questions.explanation: At speeds below 40 mph, you should allow at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle. Follow the same formula when traveling at faster speeds, then add one additional second to your following distance. Remember that larger vehicles require more space to stop than smaller vehicles.

questions.question: If planning to change lanes, your mirrors should:
questions.answerB: Be checked as usual.
questions.answerC: Be checked more often than usual.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should be part of your normal scanning routine, be especially sure to check your mirrors when changing lanes.

questions.question: If the emergency air line loses pressure:
questions.answerA: The Anti-Lock Braking System will activate.
questions.answerB: The service air line will activate.
questions.answerC: The emergency brakes will activate.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line controls the emergency brakes on a combination vehicle. A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

questions.question: In a double or triple combination, the ____ trailer should be directly behind the cab.
questions.answerB: Heaviest
questions.answerC: Smallest
questions.explanation: When positioning trailers in a combination, the most heavily-loaded trailer should be the closest to the tractor. The lightest trailer should be positioned in the rear.

questions.question: If the safety relief valve in the air brake system releases air:
questions.answerB: The air pressure has become too high.
questions.answerC: The brakes are fully operational.
questions.explanation: An air brake system has a safety relief valve, which releases air from the tanks if the pressure gets too high. If the valve must operate, something in the system is wrong and should be addressed by a mechanic.

questions.question: If you see taillights ahead while you are driving in fog:
questions.answerA: The lights may not indicate where the road is as the vehicle may have pulled off the roadway.
questions.answerB: You can assume the vehicle ahead is on the road.
questions.answerC: It may be an optical illusion.
questions.explanation: When driving under foggy conditions, lights cannot be taken as a reliable indication of where the road is. The lights may be coming from a vehicle that has pulled off the road.

questions.question: When traveling in heavy traffic, the safest driving speed is:
questions.answerB: The speed of surrounding traffic.
questions.answerC: A speed much slower than the flow of surrounding traffic.
questions.explanation: In heavy traffic, it is safest to match the speed of surrounding vehicles. Vehicles traveling in the same direction at the same speed are unlikely to collide. However, you should not exceed legal speed limits.

questions.question: Routine vehicle inspections should be done to ensure:
questions.answerB: Good gas mileage.
questions.answerC: Comfort.
questions.explanation: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle is to ensure the safety of yourself and other road users.

questions.question: Brake fade is a result of:
questions.answerB: Brakes being exposed to moisture.
questions.answerC: Excessive use of the brakes.
questions.explanation: If brakes are overused, they can become too hot. This overheating causes them to fade, making them less effective at slowing the vehicle.

questions.question: If driving so slowly that you could impede other drivers, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive while using your four-way flashers.
questions.answerC: Drive without using any lights.
questions.explanation: If you must drive so slowly that you will impede the flow of traffic, you should turn on your four-way flashers to alert drivers behind you (as long as local laws allow the use of flashers).

questions.question: If you remain in neutral for too long while switching gears:
questions.answerB: You may have trouble putting the vehicle into the next gear.
questions.answerC: You may kill the engine.
questions.explanation: If you remain in neutral for too long while switching gears, you may have difficulty putting the vehicle into the next gear. If this happens, do not try to force the gear shift. Instead, return to neutral, release the clutch, increase the engine speed to match the road speed, and try again.

questions.question: In the case of an engine fire, you should not:
questions.answerA: Turn off the engine as soon as possible.
questions.answerB: Shoot foam through the louvers.
questions.answerC: Open the hood.
questions.explanation: In the event of an engine fire, turn off the engine as soon as possible. Do not open the hood if you can avoid doing so.

questions.question: Mirrors should be used:
questions.answerA: Only when there may be an emergency.
questions.answerB: Regularly.
questions.answerC: By a helper to monitor your blind spots.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should frequently check the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle.

questions.question: What is a bobtail tractor?
questions.answerB: A tractor attached to two trailers
questions.answerC: A tractor with a tank
questions.explanation: Tractors without semi-trailers are referred to as bobtail tractors. Operating a bobtail tractor requires drivers to exercise caution.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a distracted person who should concern motorists?
questions.answerA: A driver talking to a passenger in their vehicle
questions.answerB: A person sitting on a bench waiting for a bus
questions.answerC: A construction worker on the side of the road
questions.explanation: You should be cautious when you are near people who are not paying attention to the road. Drivers and pedestrians who are talking to someone may be distracted by the conversation and not fully paying attention to the road. Workers on or near the road may not be paying attention to traffic because they are focused on their work, and can themselves also be a distraction to drivers.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are usually shaped like:
questions.answerB: Triangles.
questions.answerC: Diamonds.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are usually diamond-shaped.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerB: To check the connection between the trailer and tractor.
questions.answerC: To accelerate.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve (also referred to as the "trolley valve" or "Johnson bar") works the trailer brakes and should be used only when testing them. Using the trailer hand valve while driving could result in a skid.

questions.question: A danger of swerving to avoid a hazard while driving a large truck is that:
questions.answerA: The truck may miss the object.
questions.answerB: The truck may flip over.
questions.answerC: The truck may stay in the same lane.
questions.explanation: While swerving can sometimes be the safest way to handle a hazard on the roadway, doing so is not without risk. Top-heavy vehicles and tractors with multiple trailers may flip over in a swerve.

questions.question: If mirrors are dirty before starting a trip:
questions.answerA: They will likely become clean after driving a short distance.
questions.answerB: It should not be a concern.
questions.answerC: They should be cleaned before the vehicle is driven.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, be sure to check the mirrors and windshield for dirt and anything else that could interfere with your ability to see. Clean them as necessary.

questions.question: What is reaction distance?
questions.answerA: The distance you will travel between realizing you must brake and when you physically hit the brakes
questions.answerB: The distance you will travel between a hazard becoming visible and you seeing the hazard
questions.answerC: The distance you will travel between seeing a hazard and realizing you must brake
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's stopping distance can be calculated by adding together your perception distance, your reaction distance, and your vehicle's braking distance. Reaction distance is the distance traveled between the moment you mentally perceive a hazard and the moment you physically hit the brakes.

questions.question: Emergency equipment in a vehicle is:
questions.answerA: Only required for vehicles that are transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Only required during interstate travel.
questions.answerC: Required.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should check for emergency equipment, including spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: When traveling down a downgrade, the speed of a vehicle will likely:
questions.answerB: Stay the same.
questions.answerC: Increase.
questions.explanation: The force of gravity will cause a vehicle's speed to increase when traveling downhill.

questions.question: All trailers made after ____ must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).
questions.explanation: All trailers and converter dollies manufactured on or after March 1, 1998 must have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: To change lanes, you should:
questions.answerB: Move slowly and smoothly.
questions.answerC: Hold down your horn.
questions.explanation: Always change lanes slowly and smoothly. If you did not see drivers who are already using the lane you wish to occupy, this will give them a chance to get out of your way or honk their horns to alert you. Always signal when changing lanes.

questions.question: When driving a 50-foot truck at 50 mph, your minimum following distance should be:
questions.answerB: Five seconds.
questions.answerC: Six seconds.
questions.explanation: At speeds below 40 mph, you should allow at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle. When traveling at higher speeds, follow the same formula, then add one additional second to your following distance.

questions.question: Broken suspension parts:
questions.answerA: Are not a cause for concern.
questions.answerB: Are extremely dangerous.
questions.answerC: Cannot be identified.
questions.explanation: The suspension system holds up a vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Defects in this system are extremely dangerous.

questions.question: A driver should:
questions.answerA: Always use turn signals when changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Only use turn signals if there is a vehicle next to them.
questions.answerC: Not use a turn signal if a lane change is obvious.
questions.explanation: Always signal before turning or changing lanes to ensure that other drivers are aware of your intentions.

questions.question: Too much air pressure in a tire:
questions.answerB: Is encouraged on long drives.
questions.answerC: Can be dangerous.
questions.explanation: Tires should never have too much air pressure. Be sure to check your tires' air pressure with a gauge during inspections.

questions.question: Vehicles driving behind a truck:
questions.answerA: May have difficulty seeing objects in front of the truck.
questions.answerB: Often have a great view of the roadway in front of them.
questions.answerC: Do not need to signal.
questions.explanation: Your truck may block the views of drivers behind you, making them unaware of any upcoming hazards that require you to stop. For this reason, it is a good idea to flash your brakes and warn other drivers before slowing or stopping.

questions.question: Cargo tanks should never be completely full because:
questions.answerA: There needs to be room for the liquid to expand.
questions.answerB: Regulations require three feet of clearance between the top of the liquid and the roof of the tank.
questions.answerC: The tank would be too heavy.
questions.explanation: Liquids expand as they get warmer and drivers must allow extra space in a tank to accommodate this expansion. Different liquids expand to different degrees, so drivers must be aware of the outage requirements of the specific load they are carrying.

questions.question: On a slippery surface, stopping distance:
questions.answerA: Is longer than on a regular driving surface.
questions.answerB: Is not as long as on a regular driving surface.
questions.answerC: Is about the same as on a regular driving surface.
questions.explanation: A vehicle's regular stopping distance increases on slippery surfaces because there is less available traction.

questions.question: If you discover that your cargo is leaking, you should:
questions.answerA: Touch the leaking material to identify the cargo.
questions.answerB: Use shipping papers and labels to identify the leaking cargo.
questions.answerC: Assume all the cargo is leaking.
questions.explanation: If you discover a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, identify the materials in question by using the shipping papers, labels, or package location. Do not touch the leaking material.

questions.question: You may be an aggressive driver if you:
questions.answerB: Slow down and maintain a reasonable following distance.
questions.answerC: Make hand gestures that could anger other drivers.
questions.explanation: Avoid being an aggressive driver by being realistic about your travel time, making allowance for delays, maintaining reasonable following distances, and not making hand gestures that could anger another driver.

questions.question: If there is a fire in your vehicle, you should not:
questions.answerA: Park in an area away from buildings, trees, brush, and other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Pull into a service station.
questions.answerC: Notify emergency services of your problem and your location.
questions.explanation: In the event of a vehicle fire, you should leave the road and stop in an open area. Do not pull into a service station as fuels at the service station could catch fire. Report the fire and your location to emergency services.

questions.question: While driving a vehicle, if an unusual noise or feeling occurs, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume it is not a concern and continue driving.
questions.answerB: Hope the vehicle makes it until it is switched to another driver.
questions.answerC: Check out the situation to determine the proper solutions.
questions.explanation: Use your senses during trips to help you identify mechanical issues. If you see, hear, smell, or feel anything that could indicate trouble, you should stop and check it out.

questions.question: Before beginning a trip, you should:
questions.answerA: Leave the service line valve open.
questions.answerB: Remove the relay valves.
questions.answerC: Close the emergency line valve.
